awd_titl_txt: SCH:INT: Self-powered Smart Ring for Always-On Health Interventions
awd_abstract_narration:
Continuous monitoring is becoming increasingly more important in preventive, personalized care supporting just-in-time interventions. New sensor and communications technologies offer opportunities for more proactive models of care that reach people in their homes and everyday lives to improve health behaviors. Although wearable sensors have played an important role in technology-facilitated health interventions, maintaining use for longer than a few weeks has proven difficult for much of the population.  One substantial barrier to extended use is the need to recharge the devices, usually on a daily basis for tailored just-in-time messaging and effective interventions. Current techniques for real-time assessment and interpretation of physiological sensors require power hungry data collection, transfer, and interpretation to deliver tailored and timely feedback.  Each time a wearable device requires charging, it takes renewed motivation to charge it and additional motivation to put it back on.  The goal of this project is to create a multi-sensor comfortable self-powered ring that never needs charging.  The team will use stress monitoring and management as an important clinical challenge requiring multiple sensors and just-in-time interactions as an example to test the contributions of a multi-sensor smart ring, as well as intelligent sampling inference and transmission, to provide tailored stress coaching advice without the need for battery charging or device removal. Stress is one of the key threats to the health and productivity of the nation.  As a health hazard, it affects all major organs and is associated with many diseases and a reduction in life expectancy.  Normally, monitoring stress data and providing real-time intervention would require recharging a wearable device every 6 hours. To address this issue, the research team plans to develop an energy harvesting system on a chip (SoC) with algorithms that minimize power consumption. This system will be embedded within a comfortable waterproof ring that users never have to remove or charge.  This novel capability will enable effective health coaching interventions that require continuous engagement and feedback.

In this one-year project, the team plans to develop a prototype self-powered ring with the capability to monitor health and activity variables important in stress management interventions.  These variables include heart rate, heart rate variability, and electrodermal activity (an indicator of skin conductance).  This research group also plans to measure motion using an accelerometry sensor to provide information in distinguishing physical stress from the target classification of emotional stress.   The project will involve two main activities.  Firstly, the project will develop algorithms to minimize power consumption to enable perpetually operating sensors for stress monitoring. To accomplish this goal, the project team will first specify the clinical requirements for the monitoring and feedback protocols.  This specification will then inform signal sampling and filtering requirements, data fusion specifications, as well as guidelines for approaches to minimizing data storage and transfer.  Decision-theoretic algorithms will be used to optimize the sampling and transmission of multiple sensor data from the ring.  Existing algorithms will be optimized for stress monitoring and sensor fusion by integrating heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity and accelerometry to accurately classify stress levels in real time. The second main activity will be to develop an energy harvesting SoC with dynamic performance scaling and fabrication protocols for smart ring system integration and waterproof packaging. The project will develop a high-precision on-chip clock source and advanced power management circuitry to enable implementation of the dynamic decision algorithms and energy utilization harvested from external indoor solar cells. The team will then integrate high efficiency GaAs solar cells, dynamic sampling/transmission SoC, sensor components (photoplethysmography sensors, electrodermal activity electrodes), and wireless modules with advanced flexible encapsulation scheme into an always-on smart health monitoring ring. It is anticipated that the success of this project will generalize to markedly improve health behavior interventions and will transform the next-generation health and medical research through always-connected data, people, and systems.

Self-powered Smart Ring for Always-On Health Interventions

The goal of this one-year project was to develop the foundational techniques that would be required to implement an always-on smart ring with multiple sensors for health monitoring that would never need to be taken off for battery charging. Continuous monitoring is becoming increasingly more important in preventive, personalized care supporting just-in-time health interventions. Wearable devices of today enable the monitoring of health data, such as heart rate, activity level, electrodermal activity (skin conductance), and temperature within e-health applications. However, a common issue of wearable technology is that sensing, signal processing and transmission are power-demanding, and as such, require frequent battery charges and replacement, posing serious limitations to the continuous monitoring of health data.  We envisioned that a self-powered, waterproof smart sensing system on a ring platform would enable the always-on connectivity for users and transform healthcare from hospital to home. In this project, we used stress monitoring and management as an important clinical challenge requiring multiple sensors and just-in-time interactions as an example to test the contributions of a multi-sensor smart ring. For our project we created a new system-on-a-chip (SoC) design to harvest energy from indoor room light sources as needed, and additionally developed novel methods for intelligent data sampling, inference and transmission of data using dynamic algorithms to adjust clinical coaching messaging protocols according to battery levels.

A battery-less physiological monitoring SoC needs to harvest energy from ambient sources available in its application space. However, energy available in the ambient space is typically very low which requires new ultra–low power circuits. For the energy harvesting component of this project we developed a high-precision on-chip clock source and advanced power management circuitry to enable implementation of the dynamic decision algorithms and energy utilization harvested from external indoor solar cells. This was in preparation to integrate a high efficiency GaAs solar cell, dynamic sampling/transmission SoC, sensor components (PPG sensors, EDA electrodes, accelerometer), and wireless modules with advanced flexible encapsulation scheme into an always-on smart health monitor.  We completed the preliminary testing of the overall system and validated a double-layer PCB design with an area of 40mm*20mm for the smart ring prototype. Our unique designed ring system combines a Bluetooth chip and microcontroller together. The Bluetooth chip can be directly developed for code development, thereby reducing power consumption from the source of the number of devices. The main purpose of this work was to make our smart always-on ring as energy-efficient as possible.

For the computational component of the project, we used stress monitoring as a challenging use case requiring information from multiple sensors. Our stress detection algorithms and inferences are based on data from conventional wearable sensors with sampling rates that normally quickly deplete battery life. We use sensor fusion algorithms combining heart rate, heart rate variability, and electrodermal activity to infer the presence and characteristics of stress from moment to moment in near real time.  This allows us to capture the changing dynamics of stress in real-world contexts. In coordination with the SoC described above, and with consultation from therapists with experience in stress management, we created a high-level protocol that would incorporate the dynamic sampling and transmission of sensor data based on battery level. We designed our algorithm around 3 power modes (green, yellow and red) that represent high, medium, and low battery level respectively. In green mode, we perform continuous monitoring and provide real time intervention. In yellow mode, the reduced function mode, where only user queries are supported. In red mode, the minimal function mode, we only send a summary report. We developed our system to be easily modified to other health management applications that require ongoing communications with patients.  This approach easily generalizes to other health monitoring applications.

We anticipate that these results will facilitate the development in implementation of wearable sensors that do not need to be removed for battery charging.  Always-on wearables will likely improve individuals’ adherence to their health behavior change goals, and thus improve the quality of life and health outcomes of a considerable proportion of the population.
